message.name: The Bible tells...

test.input: What does the Bible tell?
test.output: The Bible tells who God is, our story, the suffering that is present in our heart and our thirst.
test.outputReferences: <hc_source name="Bible" resourceid="the-bible-tells" textlength="5" />

message.text: The Bible tells who God is. The Bible tells our story. The Bible tells the suffering that is present in our heart. The Bible tells of our thirst for living and being happy.

message.name: God became man

Is Jesus Christ truly God?

message.text: Jesus Christ was not always man but he became man in the womb of the Virgin Mary.

message.name: What do we call the mystery of God becoming Man?

test.input: What do we call the mystery of God becoming Man?
test.output: We call this mystery 'the Incarnation' which means that God the Son, became man, a human being like us in all things except sin. 'the Word was made Flesh and dwelt among us' (John 1:14).

message.name: Life
message.text: Jean Marie Vianney was born in Dardilly in the Rhone in 1786. Jean Marie Vianney made his first communion in the neighboring village of Écully in 1799. He worked the land with his father. In October 1809, Jean Marie Vianney was called to the army. Jean Marie Vianney was accepted at the seminary of Verrières in 1811.

message.name: Credo

test.input: What is the credo?
test.output: The credo is "I believe in God, the Father Almighty, Creator of heaven and earth. And in Jesus Christ, his only Son, our Lord: who was conceived by the Holy Spirit, born of the Virgin Mary, suffered under Pontius Pilate, was crucified, died, and was buried; he descended into hell; the third day he rose again from the dead; he ascended into heaven; sitteth at the right hand of God the Father Almighty; from thence he shall come to judge the living and the dead. I believe in the Holy Spirit, the holy Catholic Church, the communion of Saints, the forgiveness of sins, the resurrection of the body, and life everlasting. Amen.".

message.text: The credo is "I believe in God, the Father Almighty, Creator of heaven and earth. And in Jesus Christ, his only Son, our Lord: who was conceived by the Holy Spirit, born of the Virgin Mary, suffered under Pontius Pilate, was crucified, died, and was buried; he descended into hell; the third day he rose again from the dead; he ascended into heaven; sitteth at the right hand of God the Father Almighty; from thence he shall come to judge the living and the dead. I believe in the Holy Spirit, the holy Catholic Church, the communion of Saints, the forgiveness of sins, the resurrection of the body, and life everlasting. Amen."

message.name: What is the Soul?

test.input: What is the soul?
test.output: The soul is what makes every individual person a man: his spiritual life-principle and inmost being. The soul causes the material body to be a living human body. Through his soul, man is a creature who can say “I” and stand before God as an irreplaceable individual.

message.name: What is the Church?

test.input: What is the Church?
test.output: The Greek word for Church is “ekklesia” = those who are called forth. All of us who are baptized and believe in God are called forth by the Lord. Together we are the Church. Christ is, as Paul says, the Head of the Church. We are his body.|otherAnswer->|\hc_resource_html=#en_US#<iframe width="560" height="307" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/hxN24-H8lTY?rel=0" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>\

message.name: Summary of Pope Francis 'Laudato Si'

description.value: Top 10 Things You Need to Know about Pope Francis' Laudato Si'
Pope Francis' highly-anticipated environmental encyclical has arrived and Fr. James Martin, S.J., presents the ten things you need to know about it.

message.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/a_lqFTYLc_4?rel=0" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

folder.name: How We Are to Have Life in Christ

message.name: How can we distinguish serious sins (mortal sins) from less serious (venial) sins?

test.input: How can we distinguish serious sins (mortal sins) from less serious (venial) sins?
test.output: Serious sin destroys the divine power of love in a person’s heart, without which there can be no eternal beatitude. Hence it is also called mortal sin. Serious sin breaks with God, whereas venial sin only strains the relationship with him.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="1852-1861" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="1874" textlength="4" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="how-can-we-distinguish-serious-sins-mortal-sins-from-less-serious-venial-sins" textlength="6" />

test.input: What is the differences between mortal sins and venial sins?
test.output: Serious sin destroys the divine power of love in a person’s heart, without which there can be no eternal beatitude. Hence it is also called mortal sin. Serious sin breaks with God, whereas venial sin only strains the relationship with him.

test.output: A mortal sin destroys the divine power of love in a person’s heart, without which there can be no eternal beatitude. Hence it is called mortal sin. It breaks with God.

folder.name: How We Celebrate the Christian Mysteries

message.name: What is liturgy?

test.input: What is liturgy?
test.output: The liturgy is the official divine worship of the Church.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="1077-1112" textlength="9" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-liturgy" textlength="6" />

message.text: Liturgy is the official divine worship of the Church.

message.name: How did the creeds come about?

test.input: How did the creeds come about?
test.output: The creeds go back to Jesus, who commanded his disciples to baptize. In doing so, they were to require of the people seeking Baptism the profession of a definite faith, namely, faith in the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit (Trinity).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Mt 28: 19" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="188-191" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="how-did-the-creeds-come-about" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: How did the creeds come about?

message.text: The creeds go back to Jesus, who commanded his disciples to baptize. In doing so, they were to require of the people seeking Baptism the profession of a definite faith, namely, faith in the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit (Trinity).

folder.name: I Believe in God the Father

message.name: Can God do anything? Is he almighty?

test.input: Can God do anything?
test.output: “For God nothing is impossible” (see Lk 1:37). He is almighty.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Is 55: 8" textlength="8" /><hc_bible ref="Ps 135: 5-6" textlength="11" /><hc_bible ref="Mk 14: 36" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="268-278" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="can-god-do-anything-is-he-almighty" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Can God do anything?
Is God almighty?

message.text: “For God nothing is impossible” (see Lk 1:37). He is almighty.

message.name: Can someone accept the theory of evolution and still believe in the Creator?

test.input: Can someone accept the theory of evolution and still believe in the Creator?
test.output: Yes. Although it is a different kind of knowledge, faith is open to the findings and hypotheses of the sciences.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="282-289" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="can-someone-accept-the-theory-of-evolution-and-still-believe-in-the-creator" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Can someone accept the theory of evolution and still believe in the Creator?

message.text: Yes. Although it is a different kind of knowledge, faith is open to the findings and hypotheses of the sciences.

message.name: Can we deduce logically that God is triune?

test.input: Can we deduce logically that God is triune?
test.output: No. The fact that there are three persons (Trinity) in one God is a mystery. We know only through Jesus Christ that God is Trinitarian.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="237" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="can-we-deduce-logically-that-god-is-triune" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Can we deduce logically that God is triune?

message.text: No. The fact that there are three persons (Trinity) in one God is a mystery. We know only through Jesus Christ that God is Trinitarian.

message.name: Does God guide the world and my life?

test.input: Does God guide the world and my life?
test.output: Yes, but in a mysterious way; God guides everything along paths that only he knows, leading it to its perfection. At no point in time does something that he has created fall out of his hands.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="302-305" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="does-god-guide-the-world-and-my-life" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Does God guide the world and my life?

message.text: Yes, but in a mysterious way; God guides everything along paths that only he knows, leading it to its perfection. At no point in time does something that he has created fall out of his hands.

message.name: If God is all-knowing and all-powerful, why does he not prevent evil?

test.input: If God is all-knowing and all-powerful, why does he not prevent evil?
test.output: “God allows evil only so as to make something better result from it” (St. Thomas Aquinas).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Rom 8: 18" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Mt 27: 46" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="309-314" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="324" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="if-god-is-all-knowing-and-all-powerful-why-does-he-not-prevent-evil" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: If God is all-knowing and all-powerful, why does he not prevent evil?

message.text: “God allows evil only so as to make something better result from it” (St. Thomas Aquinas).

message.name: What role does man play in God’s providence?

test.input: What role does man play in God’s providence?
test.output: The completion of creation through divine providence is not something that happens above and beyond us. God invites us to collaborate in the completion of creation.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Mt 10: 30" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="307-308" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-role-does-man-play-in-god-s-providence" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What role does man play in God’s providence?

message.text: The completion of creation through divine providence is not something that happens above and beyond us. God invites us to collaborate in the completion of creation.

message.name: Do natural laws and natural systems come from God also?

test.input: Do natural laws and natural systems come from God also?
test.output: Yes. The laws of nature and natural systems are also part of God’s creation.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Rev 4: 11" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="339" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="346" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="354" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="do-natural-laws-and-natural-systems-come-from-god-also" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Do natural laws and natural systems come from God also?

message.text: Yes. The laws of nature and natural systems are also part of God’s creation.

message.name: Do we believe in one God or in three Gods?

test.input: Do we believe in one God or in three Gods?
test.output: I don't know if we believe in 1 God.

trigger.value: Do we believe in one God or in three Gods?

message.text: We believe in one God in three persons (Trinity). “God is not solitude but perfect communion.” (Pope Benedict XVI, May 22, 2005).

message.name: Does science make the Creator superfluous?

test.input: Does science make the Creator superfluous?
test.output: No. The sentence “God created the world” is not an outmoded scientific statement. We are dealing here with a theo-logical statement, therefore a statement about the divine meaning (theos = God, logos = meaning) and origin of things.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Wis 11: 24" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="282-289" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="does-science-make-the-creator-superfluous" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Does science make the Creator superfluous?

message.text: No. The sentence “God created the world” is not an outmoded scientific statement. We are dealing here with a theo-logical statement, therefore a statement about the divine meaning (theos = God, logos = meaning) and origin of things.

message.name: Are we compelled to sin by original sin?

test.input: Are we compelled to sin by original sin?
test.output: No. Man, though, is deeply wounded by original sin and is inclined to sin. Nevertheless, with God’s help he is capable of doing good.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="405" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="are-we-compelled-to-sin-by-original-sin" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Are we compelled to sin by original sin?

message.text: No. Man, though, is deeply wounded by original sin and is inclined to sin. Nevertheless, with God’s help he is capable of doing good.

message.name: How does God draw us out of the whirlpool of evil?

test.input: How does God draw us out of the whirlpool of evil?
test.output: God does not just look on as man gradually destroys himself and the world around him through the chain reaction of sin. He sends us Jesus Christ, the Savior and Redeemer, who snatches us from the power of sin.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="410-412" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="420-421" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="how-does-god-draw-us-out-of-the-whirlpool-of-evil" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: How does God draw us out of the whirlpool of evil?

message.text: God does not just look on as man gradually destroys himself and the world around him through the chain reaction of sin. He sends us Jesus Christ, the Savior and Redeemer, who snatches us from the power of sin.

message.name: What is Original sin?

test.input: What is Original sin?
test.output: Sin in the strict sense implies guilt for which one is personally responsible. Therefore the term “Original Sin” refers, not to a personal sin, but rather to the disastrous, fallen state of mankind into which the individual is born, even before he himself sins by a free decision.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Gen 3: 4-5" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="388-389" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="402-404" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-original-sin-fallen-man" textlength="6" />

test.input: What does the Fall of Adam and Eve have to do with us?
test.output: Sin in the strict sense implies guilt for which one is personally responsible. Therefore the term “Original Sin” refers, not to a personal sin, but rather to the disastrous, fallen state of mankind into which the individual is born, even before he himself sins by a free decision.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Gen 3: 4-5" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="388-389" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="402-404" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-original-sin-fallen-man" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is Original sin?
What does the Fall of Adam and Eve have to do with us?

message.text: Sin in the strict sense implies guilt for which one is personally responsible. Therefore the term “Original Sin” refers, not to a personal sin, but rather to the disastrous, fallen state of mankind into which the individual is born, even before he himself sins by a free decision.

message.name: What is sin?

test.input: What is sin?
test.output: At the core of sin is a rejection of God and the refusal to accept his love. This is manifested in a disregard for his commandments.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="385-390" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-sin" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is sin?

message.text: At the core of sin is a rejection of God and the refusal to accept his love. This is manifested in a disregard for his commandments.

message.name: Can we interact with angels?

test.input: Can we interact with angels?
test.output: Yes. We can call on angels for help and ask them to intercede with God.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="334-336" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="352" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="can-we-interact-with-angels" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Can we interact with angels?

message.text: Yes. We can call on angels for help and ask them to intercede with God.

message.name: What are angels?

test.input: What are angels?
test.output: Angels are pure spiritual creatures of God who have understanding and will. They have no bodies, cannot die, and are usually not visible. They live constantly in God’s presence and convey God’s will and God’s protection to men.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="328-333" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="350-351" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-are-angels" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What are angels?

message.text: Angels are pure spiritual creatures of God who have understanding and will. They have no bodies, cannot die, and are usually not visible.They live constantly in God’s presence and convey God’s will and God’s protection to men.

message.name: What is heaven?

test.input: What is heaven?
test.output: Heaven is God’s milieu, the dwelling place of the angels and saints, and the goal of creation. With the words “heaven and earth” we designate the whole of created reality.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="325-327" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-heaven" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is heaven?

message.text: Heaven is God’s milieu, the dwelling place of the angels and saints, and the goal of creation. With the words “heaven and earth” we designate the whole of created reality.

message.name: What is hell?

test.input: What is hell?
test.output: Our faith calls “hell” the condition of final separation from God. Anyone who sees love clearly in the face of God and, nevertheless, does not want it decides freely to have this condition instead.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="1033-1036" textlength="9" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-hell-divine-providence" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is hell?

message.text: Our faith calls “hell” the condition of final separation from God. Anyone who sees love clearly in the face of God and, nevertheless, does not want it decides freely to have this condition instead.

message.name: Is Jesus God? Does he belong to the Trinity?

test.input: Is Jesus God?
test.output: Jesus of Nazareth is the Son, the second divine person mentioned when we pray, “In the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit” (Mt 28:19).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 13: 13" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Acts 4: 12" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="243-260" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="is-jesus-god-does-he-belong-to-the-trinity" textlength="6" />

test.input: Does Jesus belong to the Trinity?
test.output: Jesus of Nazareth is the Son, the second divine person mentioned when we pray, “In the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit” (Mt 28:19).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 13: 13" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Acts 4: 12" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="243-260" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="is-jesus-god-does-he-belong-to-the-trinity" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Is Jesus God?
Does Jesus belong to the Trinity?

message.text: Jesus of Nazareth is the Son, the second divine person mentioned when we pray, “In the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit” (Mt 28:19).

message.name: Is the world a product of chance?

test.input: Is the world a product of chance?
test.output: No. God, not chance, is the cause of the world. Neither in its origin nor with respect to its intrinsic order and purposefulness is it the product of factors working “aimlessly”.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="295-301" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="317-318" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="320" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="is-the-world-a-product-of-chance" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Is the world a product of chance?

message.text: No. God, not chance, is the cause of the world. Neither in its origin nor with respect to its intrinsic order and purposefulness is it the product of factors working “aimlessly”.

message.name: Does man have a special place in creation?

test.input: Does man have a special place in creation?
test.output: Yes. Man is the summit of creation, because God created him in his image.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Gen 1: 27" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Ps 8: 4-6" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="343-344" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="353" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="does-man-have-a-special-place-in-creation" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Does man have a special place in creation?

message.text: Yes. Man is the summit of creation, because God created him in his image.

message.name: From where does man get his soul?

test.input: From where does man get his soul?
test.output: The human soul is created directly by God and is not “produced” by the parents.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="366-368" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="382" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="from-where-does-man-get-his-soul" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: From where does man get his soul?

message.text: The human soul is created directly by God and is not “produced” by the parents.

message.name: How should man treat animals and other fellow creatures?

test.input: How should man treat animals and other fellow creatures?
test.output: Man should honor the Creator in other creatures and treat them carefully and responsibly. Man,animals, and plants have the same Creator who called them into being out of love. Therefore a love of animals is profoundly human.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="344" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="354" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="how-should-man-treat-animals-and-other-fellow-creatures" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: How should man treat animals and other fellow creatures?

message.text: Man should honor the Creator in other creatures and treat them carefully and responsibly. Man,animals, and plants have the same Creator who called them into being out of love. Therefore a love of animals is profoundly human.

message.name: In what does the equality of all men consist?

test.input: In what does the equality of all men consist?
test.output: All men are equal inasmuch as they have the same origin in the one creative love of God. All men have their Savior in Jesus Christ. All men are destined to find their happiness and their eternal blessedness in God.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Prov 31: 8" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="360-361" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="in-what-does-the-equality-of-all-men-consist" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: In what does the equality of all men consist?

message.text: All men are equal inasmuch as they have the same origin in the one creative love of God. All men have their Savior in Jesus Christ. All men are destined to find their happiness and their eternal blessedness in God.

message.name: Was it part of God’s plan for men to suffer and die?

test.input: Was it part of God’s plan for men to suffer and die?
test.output: God does not want men to suffer and die. God’s original idea for man was paradise: life forever and peace between God and man and their environment, between man and woman.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="374-379" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="384" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="400" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="was-it-part-of-god-s-plan-for-men-to-suffer-and-die" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Was it part of God’s plan for men to suffer and die?

message.text: God does not want men to suffer and die. God’s original idea for man was paradise: life forever and peace between God and man and their environment, between man and woman.

message.name: What about people who feel they are homosexual?

test.input: What about people who feel they are homosexual?
test.output: The Church believes that, in the order of creation, man and woman are designed to need each other’s complementary traits and to enter into a mutual relationship so as to give life to children. That is why homosexual practices cannot be approved by the Church. Christians owe all persons respect and love, however, regardless of their sexual orientation, because all people are respected and loved by God.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="2358-2359" textlength="9" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-about-people-who-feel-they-are-homosexual" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What about people who feel they are homosexual?

message.text: The Church believes that, in the order of creation, man and woman are designed to need each other’s complementary traits and to enter into a mutual relationship so as to give life to children. That is why homosexual practices cannot be approved by the Church. Christians owe all persons respect and love, however, regardless of their sexual orientation, because all people are respected and loved by God.

message.name: What does it mean to say that man was created “in God’s image”?

test.input: What does it mean to say that man was created “in God’s image”?
test.output: Unlike inanimate objects, plants, and animals, man is a person endowed with a spirit. This characteristic unites him with God more than with his visible fellow creatures.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="1 Jn 4: 7" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="355-357" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="380" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-that-man-was-created-in-god-s-image" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say that man was created “in God’s image”?

message.text: Unlike inanimate objects, plants, and animals, man is a person endowed with a spirit. This characteristic unites him with God more than with his visible fellow creatures.

message.name: What is the soul?

test.input: What is the soul?
test.output: The soul is what makes every individual person a man: his spiritual life-principle and inmost being. The soul causes the material body to be a living human body. Through his soul, man is a creature who can say “I” and stand before God as an irreplaceable individual.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="362-365" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="382" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-the-soul-man-the-creature" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is the soul?

message.text: The soul is what makes every individual person a man: his spiritual life-principle and inmost being. The soul causes the material body to be a living human body. Through his soul, man is a creature who can say “I” and stand before God as an irreplaceable individual.

message.name: Why did God create man male and female?

test.input: Why did God create man male and female?
test.output: God, who is love and the archetype of community, created man male and female so that together they might be an image of his nature.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Gen 1: 27" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Gen 2: 18" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="369-373" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="383" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-did-god-create-man-male-and-female" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why did God create man male and female?

message.text: God, who is love and the archetype of community, created man male and female so that together they might be an image of his nature.

message.name: Why did God make man?

test.input: Why did God make man?
test.output: God made everything for man. Man, however, who is “the only creature on earth that God has willed for its own sake” (GS 24, 3), was created in order to be blessed. This happens when he knows, loves, and serves God and lives in gratitude toward his Creator.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="358" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-did-god-make-man" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why did God make man?

message.text: God made everything for man. Man, however, who is “the only creature on earth that God has willed for its own sake” (GS 24, 3), was created in order to be blessed. This happens when he knows, loves, and serves God and lives in gratitude toward his Creator.

message.name: Why is Jesus the greatest example in the world?

test.input: Why is Jesus the greatest example in the world?
test.output: Jesus Christ is unique because he shows us not only God’s true nature but also the true ideal of man.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Col 1: 15-16" textlength="12" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 19: 5" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="358-359" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="381" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-is-jesus-the-greatest-example-in-the-world" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why is Jesus the greatest example in the world?

message.text: Jesus Christ is unique because he shows us not only God’s true nature but also the true ideal of man.

message.name: What does it mean to say that God is love?

test.input: What does it mean to say that God is love?
test.output: If God is love, then there is nothing created that is not carried and surrounded by his infinite benevolence. God not only declares that he is love, he also proves it: “Greater love has no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends” (Jn 15:13).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="1 Jn 4: 8" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="1 Jn 4: 16" textlength="10" /><hc_bible ref="Is 43: 4-5" textlength="10" /><hc_bible ref="Is 49: 15-16" textlength="12" /><hc_ccc ref="218-221" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-that-god-is-love" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say that God is love?

message.text: If God is love, then there is nothing created that is not carried and surrounded by his infinite benevolence. God not only declares that he is love, he also proves it: “Greater love has no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends” (Jn 15:13).

message.name: What does it mean to say that God is truth?

test.input: What does it mean to say that God is truth?
test.output: “God is light and in him is no darkness” (1 Jn 1:5). His Word is truth (Prov 8:7 ; 2 Sam 7:28), and his Law is truth (Ps 119:142). Jesus himself vouches for God’s truth by declaring before Pilate, “For this I was born, and for this I have come into the world, to bear witness to the truth” (Jn 18:37).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 14: 6" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="214-217" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-that-god-is-truth" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say that God is truth?

message.text: “God is light and in him is no darkness” (1 Jn 1:5). His Word is truth (Prov 8:7 ; 2 Sam 7:28), and his Law is truth (Ps 119:142). Jesus himself vouches for God’s truth by declaring before Pilate, “For this I was born, and for this I have come into the world, to bear witness to the truth” (Jn 18:37).

message.name: What should you do once you have come to know God?

test.input: What should you do once you have come to know God?
test.output: Once you have come to know God, you must put him in the first place in your life. And with that a new life begins. You should be able to recognize Christians by the fact that they love even their enemies.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="222-227" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="229" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-should-you-do-once-you-have-come-to-know-god" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What should you do once you have come to know God?

message.text: Once you have come to know God, you must put him in the first place in your life. And with that a new life begins. You should be able to recognize Christians by the fact that they love even their enemies.

message.name: Who created the world?

test.input: Who created the world?
test.output: God alone, who is beyond time and space, created the world out of nothing and called all things into being. Everything that exists depends on God and continues in being only because God wills it to be.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Col 1: 16" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="290-292" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="316" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="who-created-the-world" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Who created the world?

message.text: God alone, who is beyond time and space, created the world out of nothing and called all things into being. Everything that exists depends on God and continues in being only because God wills it to be.

message.name: Who is the “Holy Spirit”?

test.input: Who is the “Holy Spirit”?
test.output: The Holy Spirit is the third person of the Holy Trinity and has the same divine majesty as the Father and the Son.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Gal 4: 6" textlength="8" /><hc_bible ref="Rom 8: 15" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="243-248" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="263-264" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="who-is-the-holy-spirit-i-believe-in-god-the-father" textlength="6" />

message.name: Why did God create the world?

test.input: Why did God create the world?
test.output: “The world was made for the glory of God” (First Vatican Council).
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="293-294" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="319" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-did-god-create-the-world" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why did God create the world?

message.text: “The world was made for the glory of God” (First Vatican Council).

message.name: Why did God rest on the seventh day?

test.input: Why did God rest on the seventh day?
test.output: God’s rest from his work points toward the completion of creation, which is beyond all human efforts.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="349" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-did-god-rest-on-the-seventh-day" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why did God rest on the seventh day?

message.text: God’s rest from his work points toward the completion of creation, which is beyond all human efforts.

message.name: Why do we believe in only one God?

test.input: Why do we believe in only one God?
test.output: I don't know why we believe in only 1 God.

trigger.value: Why do we believe in only one God?

message.text: We believe in only one God because, according to the testimony of Sacred Scripture, there is only one God and, according to the laws of logic, there can be only one.

message.name: Why does God give himself a name?

test.input: Why does God give himself a name?
test.output: God gives himself a name so as to make it possible to address him.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Ex 3: 14" textlength="8" /><hc_bible ref="Rom 10: 9" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="203-213" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="230-231" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-does-god-give-himself-a-name" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why does God give himself a name?

message.text: God gives himself a name so as to make it possible to address him.

message.name: Why does the Book of Genesis depict creation as “the work of six days”?

test.input: Why does the Book of Genesis depict creation as “the work of six days”?

trigger.value: Why does the Book of Genesis depict creation as “the work of six days”?

message.text: The symbol of the work week, which is crowned by a day of rest (Gen 1:1-2:3), is an expression of how good, beautiful, and wisely ordered creation is.

message.name: Why is God “Father”?

test.input: Why is God “Father”?
test.output: We revere God as Father first of all because he is the Creator and cares lovingly for his creatures. Jesus, the Son of God, has taught us, furthermore, to regard his Father as our Father and to address him as “our Father”.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Deut 32: 6" textlength="10" /><hc_bible ref="Mal 2: 10" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Is 66: 13" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 14: 9" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="238-240" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-is-god-father" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why is God “Father”?

message.text: We revere God as Father first of all because he is the Creator and cares lovingly for his creatures. Jesus, the Son of God, has taught us, furthermore, to regard his Father as our Father and to address him as “our Father”.

folder.name: I Believe in Jesus Christ, the Only Begotten Son of God

message.name: Are the Jews guilty of Jesus’ death?

test.input: Are the Jews guilty of Jesus’ death?
test.output: No one can assign collective guilt for the death of Jesus to the Jews. Instead, the Church professes with certainty that all sinners share in the guilt for Jesus’ death.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Lk 2: 34" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="597-598" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="are-the-jews-guilty-of-jesus-death" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Are the Jews guilty of Jesus’ death?

message.text: No one can assign collective guilt for the death of Jesus to the Jews. Instead, the Church professes with certainty that all sinners share in the guilt for Jesus’ death.

message.name: Are there proofs for the Resurrection of Jesus?

test.input: Are there proofs for the Resurrection of Jesus?
test.output: There are no proofs for the Resurrection of Jesus in the scientific sense. There are, however, very strong individual and collective testimonies by a large number of contemporaries of those events in Jerusalem.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="1 Cor 15: 3-6" textlength="13" /><hc_bible ref="Lk 24: 5-6" textlength="10" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 20: 8" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="639-644" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="647" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="656-657" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="are-there-proofs-for-the-resurrection-of-jesus" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Are there proofs for the Resurrection of Jesus?

message.text: There are no proofs for the Resurrection of Jesus in the scientific sense. There are, however, very strong individual and collective testimonies by a large number of contemporaries of those events in Jerusalem.

message.name: But why did Jesus work miracles?

test.input: But why did Jesus work miracles?

trigger.value: But why did Jesus work miracles?

message.text: The miracles that Jesus worked were signs that the kingdom of God was beginning. They expressed his love for mankind and reaffirmed his mission.

message.name: Can you be a Christian without believing in the Resurrection of Christ?

test.input: Can you be a Christian without believing in the Resurrection of Christ?
test.output: No. “If Christ has not been raised, then our preaching is in vain and your faith is in vain” (1 Cor 15:14).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="1 Cor 15: 14" textlength="12" /><hc_ccc ref="631" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="638" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="651" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="can-you-be-a-christian-without-believing-in-the-resurrection-of-christ" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Can you be a Christian without believing in the Resurrection of Christ?

message.text: No. “If Christ has not been raised, then our preaching is in vain and your faith is in vain” (1 Cor 15:14).

message.name: Did God will the death of his only Son?

test.input: Did God will the death of his only Son?
test.output: The violent death of Jesus did not come about through tragic external circumstances. Jesus was “delivered up according to the definite plan and foreknowledge of God” (Acts 2:23). So that we children of sin and death might have life, the Father in heaven “made him to be sin who knew no sin” (2 Cor 5:21). The magnitude of the sacrifice that God the Father asked of his Son, corresponded to the magnitude of Christ’s obedience: “And what shall I say? ‘Father, save me from this hour’? No, for this purpose I have come to this hour” (Jn 12:27). On both sides, God’s love for men proved itself to the very end on the Cross.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Acts 2: 23" textlength="10" /><hc_bible ref="2 Cor 5: 21" textlength="11" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 12: 27" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 13: 1" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="599-609" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="620" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="did-god-will-the-death-of-his-only-son" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Did God will the death of his only Son?

message.text: The violent death of Jesus did not come about through tragic external circumstances. Jesus was “delivered up according to the definite plan and foreknowledge of God” (Acts 2:23). So that we children of sin and death might have life, the Father in heaven “made him to be sin who knew no sin” (2 Cor 5:21). The magnitude of the sacrifice that God the Father asked of his Son, corresponded to the magnitude of Christ’s obedience: “And what shall I say? ‘Father, save me from this hour’? No, for this purpose I have come to this hour” (Jn 12:27). On both sides, God’s love for men proved itself to the very end on the Cross.

message.name: Did Jesus have a soul, a mind, and a body just as we do?

test.input: Did Jesus have a soul, a mind, and a body just as we do?
test.output: Yes. Jesus “worked with human hands, he thought with a human mind. He acted with a human will, and with a human heart he loved” (Second Vatican Council, GS 22, 2).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Lk 2: 52" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="470-476" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="did-jesus-have-a-soul-a-mind-and-a-body-just-as-we-do" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Did Jesus have a soul, a mind, and a body just as we do?

message.text: Yes. Jesus “worked with human hands, he thought with a human mind. He acted with a human will, and with a human heart he loved” (Second Vatican Council, GS 22, 2).

message.name: Did Jesus know that he would die when he entered Jerusalem?

test.input: Did Jesus know that he would die when he entered Jerusalem?
test.output: Yes. Three times Jesus had predicted his suffering and death before consciously and voluntarily (Lk 9:51) going to the place of his Passion and his resurrection.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Lk 9: 51" textlength="8" /><hc_bible ref="Mk 10: 32-34" textlength="12" /><hc_bible ref="Lk 22: 14-16" textlength="12" /><hc_ccc ref="557-560" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="569-570" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="did-jesus-know-that-he-would-die-when-he-entered-jerusalem" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Did Jesus know that he would die when he entered Jerusalem?

message.text: Yes. Three times Jesus had predicted his suffering and death before consciously and voluntarily (Lk 9:51) going to the place of his Passion and his resurrection.

message.name: Did Jesus work miracles, or are they just pious tales?

test.input: Did Jesus work miracles, or are they just pious tales?
test.output: Jesus really worked miracles, and so did the Apostles . The New Testament authors refer to real incidents.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Lk 4: 18-19" textlength="11" /><hc_bible ref="Mt 12: 28" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Mk 10: 46-52" textlength="12" /><hc_bible ref="Mt 8: 14-15" textlength="11" /><hc_ccc ref="547-550" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="did-jesus-work-miracles-or-are-they-just-pious-tales" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Did Jesus work miracles, or are they just pious tales?

message.text: Jesus really worked miracles, and so did the Apostles . The New Testament authors refer to real incidents.

message.name: Did Mary have other children besides Jesus?

test.input: Did Mary have other children besides Jesus?
test.output: No. Jesus is the only son of Mary in the physical sense.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="500" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="510" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="did-mary-have-other-children-besides-jesus" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Did Mary have other children besides Jesus?

message.text: No. Jesus is the only son of Mary in the physical sense.

message.name: How did the disciples come to believe that Jesus is risen?

test.input: How did the disciples come to believe that Jesus is risen?
test.output: The disciples, who before had lost all hope, came to believe in Jesus’ Resurrection because they saw him in a different way after his death, spoke with him, and experienced him as being alive.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Lk 24: 21" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="640-644" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="656" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="how-did-the-disciples-come-to-believe-that-jesus-is-risen" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: How did the disciples come to believe that Jesus is risen?

message.text: The disciples, who before had lost all hope, came to believe in Jesus’ Resurrection because they saw him in a different way after his death, spoke with him, and experienced him as being alive.

message.name: Isn’t it improper to call Mary the “Mother” of God?

test.input: Isn’t it improper to call Mary the “Mother” of God?
test.output: No. Anyone who calls Mary the Mother of God thereby professes that her Son is God.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Mt 1: 23" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="495" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="509" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="isn-t-it-improper-to-call-mary-the-mother-of-god" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Isn’t it improper to call Mary the “Mother” of God?

message.text: No. Anyone who calls Mary the Mother of God thereby professes that her Son is God.

message.name: On the Mount of Olives on the night before his death, did Jesus really experience fear of death?

test.input: On the Mount of Olives on the night before his death, did Jesus really experience fear of death?
test.output: What is Olives' Mount?

trigger.value: On the Mount of Olives on the night before his death, did Jesus really experience fear of death?

message.text: Since Jesus was true man, he truly experienced fear of death on the Mount of Olives.

message.name: Through his Resurrection, did Jesus return to the physical, corporeal state that he had during his earthly life?

test.input: Through his Resurrection, did Jesus return to the physical, corporeal state that he had during his earthly life?
test.output: The risen Lord allowed his disciples to touch him; he ate with them and showed them the wounds of his Passion. Nevertheless, his body belonged no longer only to this earth, but rather to the heavenly kingdom of his Father.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 20: 16" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Rom 6: 9" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="645-646" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="through-his-resurrection-did-jesus-return-to-the-physical-corporeal-state-that-he-had-during-his-earthly-life" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Through his Resurrection, did Jesus return to the physical, corporeal state that he had during his earthly life?

message.text: The risen Lord allowed his disciples to touch him; he ate with them and showed them the wounds of his Passion. Nevertheless, his body belonged no longer only to this earth, but rather to the heavenly kingdom of his Father.

message.name: To whom does Jesus promise “the kingdom of God”?

test.input: To whom does Jesus promise “the kingdom of God”?
test.output: God wills “all men to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth” (1 Tim 2:4). The “kingdom of God” begins in those who allow themselves to be transformed by God’s love. In Jesus’ experience these are above all the poor and the lowly.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="1 Tim 2: 4" textlength="10" /><hc_bible ref="Mk 2: 17" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="541-546" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="567" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="to-whom-does-jesus-promise-the-kingdom-of-god" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: To whom does Jesus promise “the kingdom of God”?

message.text: God wills “all men to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth” (1 Tim 2:4). The “kingdom of God” begins in those who allow themselves to be transformed by God’s love. In Jesus’ experience these are above all the poor and the lowly.

message.name: Was Jesus really dead? Maybe he was able to rise again because he only appeared to have suffered death.

test.input: Was Jesus really dead? Maybe he was able to rise again because he only appeared to have suffered death.
test.output: Jesus really died on the Cross; his body was buried. All the sources testify to this.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 19: 33" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="627" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="was-jesus-really-dead-maybe-he-was-able-to-rise-again-because-he-only-appeared-to-have-suffered-death" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Was Jesus really dead? Maybe he was able to rise again because he only appeared to have suffered death.

message.text: Jesus really died on the Cross; his body was buried. All the sources testify to this.

message.name: Was Mary only an instrument of God?

test.input: Was Mary only an instrument of God?
test.output: Mary was more than a merely passive instrument of God. The Incarnation of God took place through her active consent as well.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Lk 1: 38" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="493-494" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="508-511" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="was-mary-only-an-instrument-of-god" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Was Mary only an instrument of God?

message.text: Mary was more than a merely passive instrument of God. The Incarnation of God took place through her active consent as well.

message.name: What changed in the world as a result of the Resurrection?

test.input: What changed in the world as a result of the Resurrection?
test.output: Because death is now no longer the end of everything, joy and hope came into the world. Now that death “no longer has dominion” (Rom 6:9) over Jesus, it has no more power over us, either, who belong to Jesus.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Rom 6: 9" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="655" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="658" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-changed-in-the-world-as-a-result-of-the-resurrection" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What changed in the world as a result of the Resurrection?

message.text: Because death is now no longer the end of everything, joy and hope came into the world. Now that death “no longer has dominion” (Rom 6:9) over Jesus, it has no more power over us, either, who belong to Jesus.

message.name: What does it mean to say that Jesus Christ is at the same time true God and true man?

test.input: What does it mean to say that Jesus Christ is at the same time true God and true man?
test.output: In Jesus, God really became one of us and thus our brother; nevertheless, he did not cease to be God at the same time and thus our Lord. The Council of Chalcedon in the year 451 taught that the divinity and the humanity in the one person Jesus Christ are united together “without division or confusion”.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="464-467" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="469" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-that-jesus-christ-is-at-the-same-time-true-god-and-true-man" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say that Jesus Christ is at the same time true God and true man?

message.text: In Jesus, God really became one of us and thus our brother; nevertheless, he did not cease to be God at the same time and thus our Lord.The Council of Chalcedon in the year 451 taught that the divinity and the humanity in the one person Jesus Christ are united together “without division or confusion”.

message.name: What does it mean to say that Jesus ascended into heaven?

test.input: What does it mean to say that Jesus ascended into heaven?
test.output: With Jesus, one of us has arrived home with God and remains there forever. In his Son, God is close to us men in a human way. Moreover, Jesus says in the Gospel of John, “And I, when I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all men to myself” (Jn 12:32).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 12: 32" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Acts 1: 11" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="659-667" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-that-jesus-ascended-into-heaven" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say that Jesus ascended into heaven?

message.text: With Jesus, one of us has arrived home with God and remains there forever. In his Son, God is close to us men in a human way. Moreover, Jesus says in the Gospel of John, “And I, when I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all men to myself” (Jn 12:32).

message.name: What does it mean to say that Jesus is “the only-begotten Son of God”?

test.input: What does it mean to say that Jesus is “the only-begotten Son of God”?
test.output: When Jesus calls himself “God’s only-begotten Son” (or “only Son”, Jn 3:16) and Peter and others bear witness to this, the expression means that of all men only Jesus is more than a man.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 3: 16" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="441-445" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="454" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-that-jesus-is-the-only-begotten-son-of-god" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say that Jesus is “the only-begotten Son of God”?

message.text: When Jesus calls himself “God’s only-begotten Son” (or “only Son”, Jn 3:16) and Peter and others bear witness to this, the expression means that of all men only Jesus is more than a man.

message.name: What does the name “Jesus” mean?

test.input: What does the name “Jesus” mean?
test.output: Jesus means in Hebrew “God saves.”
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Acts 4: 12" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="430-435" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="452" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-the-name-jesus-mean" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does the name “Jesus” mean?

message.text: Jesus means in Hebrew “God saves.”

message.name: What does the “Immaculate Conception of Mary” mean?

test.input: What does the “Immaculate Conception of Mary” mean?
test.output: The Church believes that “the most Blessed Virgin Mary was, from the first moment of her conception, by a singular grace and privilege of almighty God and by virtue of the merits of Jesus Christ, Savior of the human race, preserved immune from all stain of original sin” (Dogma of 1854).
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="487-492" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="508" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-the-immaculate-conception-of-mary-mean" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does the “Immaculate Conception of Mary” mean?

message.text: The Church believes that “the most Blessed Virgin Mary was, from the first moment of her conception, by a singular grace and privilege of almighty God and by virtue of the merits of Jesus Christ, Savior of the human race, preserved immune from all stain of original sin” (Dogma of 1854).

message.name: What happened at the Last Supper?

test.input: What happened at the Last Supper?
test.output: Jesus washed the feet of his apostles on the evening before his death; he instituted the Eucharist and founded the priesthood of the New Covenant.

message.text: Jesus washed the feet of his apostles on the evening before his death; he instituted the Eucharist and founded the priesthood of the New Covenant.

message.name: What will it be like when Christ judges us and the whole world?

test.input: What will it be like when Christ judges us and the whole world?
test.output: Even Christ cannot help someone who does not want to know anything about love; such a person judges himself.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 14: 6" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="678-679" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="681-682" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-will-it-be-like-when-christ-judges-us-and-the-whole-world" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What will it be like when Christ judges us and the whole world?

message.text: Even Christ cannot help someone who does not want to know anything about love; such a person judges himself.

message.name: What will it be like when the world comes to an end?

test.input: What will it be like when the world comes to an end?
test.output: When the world comes to an end, Christ comes—for all to see.

trigger.value: What will it be like when the world comes to an end?

message.text: When the world comes to an end, Christ comes—for all to see.

message.name: Why are the reports about Jesus called “the Gospel”, “the Good News”?

test.input: Why are the reports about Jesus called “the Gospel”, “the Good News”?
test.output: Without the Gospels we would not know that God sends his Son to us men out of his infinite love, so that despite our sins we might find our way back to eternal fellowship with God.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 1: 14" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="422-429" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-are-the-reports-about-jesus-called-the-gospel-the-good-news" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why are the reports about Jesus called “the Gospel”, “the Good News”?

message.text: Without the Gospels we would not know that God sends his Son to us men out of his infinite love, so that despite our sins we might find our way back to eternal fellowship with God.

message.name: Why are we too supposed to accept suffering in our lives and thus “take up our cross” and thereby follow Jesus?

test.input: Why are we too supposed to accept suffering in our lives and thus “take up our cross” and thereby follow Jesus?
test.output: Christians should not seek suffering, but when they are confronted with unavoidable suffering, it can become meaningful for them if they unite their sufferings with the sufferings of Christ: “Christ . . . suffered for you, leaving you an example, that you should follow in his steps” (1 Pet2:21).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="1 Pet 2: 21" textlength="11" /><hc_bible ref="Mk 8: 34" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="618" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-are-we-too-supposed-to-accept-suffering-in-our-lives-and-thus-take-up-our-cross-and-thereby-follow-jesus" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why are we too supposed to accept suffering in our lives and thus “take up our cross” and thereby follow Jesus?

message.text: Christians should not seek suffering, but when they are confronted with unavoidable suffering, it can become meaningful for them if they unite their sufferings with the sufferings of Christ: “Christ . . . suffered for you, leaving you an example, that you should follow in his steps” (1 Pet2:21).

message.name: Why can we grasp Jesus only as a “mystery”?

test.input: Why can we grasp Jesus only as a “mystery”?
test.output: Jesus extends into God; therefore we cannot understand him if we exclude the invisible divine reality.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="525-530" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="536" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-can-we-grasp-jesus-only-as-a-mystery" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why can we grasp Jesus only as a “mystery”?

message.text: Jesus extends into God; therefore we cannot understand him if we exclude the invisible divine reality.

message.name: Why did God become man in Jesus?

test.input: Why did God become man in Jesus?
test.output: “For us men and for our salvation he came down from heaven” (Nicene → CREED).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 3: 16" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="456-460" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-did-god-become-man-in-jesus" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why did God become man in Jesus?

message.text: “For us men and for our salvation he came down from heaven” (Nicene → CREED).

message.name: Why did Jesus allow John to baptize him, although he was without sin?

test.input: Why did Jesus allow John to baptize him, although he was without sin?
test.output: To baptize means to immerse. In his baptism, Jesus descended into the sinful history of all mankind. By doing so he established a sign. In order to redeem us from our sins, he would one day be submerged in death but, through his Father’s power, reawakened to life.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Lk 3: 3" textlength="7" /><hc_bible ref="Lk 3: 22" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="535-537" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="565" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-did-jesus-allow-john-to-baptize-him-although-he-was-without-sin" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why did Jesus allow John to baptize him, although he was without sin?

message.text: To baptize means to immerse. In his baptism, Jesus descended into the sinful history of all mankind. By doing so he established a sign. In order to redeem us from our sins, he would one day be submerged in death but, through his Father’s power, reawakened to life.

message.name: Why did Jesus call apostles?

test.input: Why did Jesus call apostles?
test.output: Jesus had a large circle of disciples around him, both men and women. From this circle he selected twelve men whom he called → APOSTLES (Lk 6:12-16). The apostles were specially trained by him and entrusted with various commissions: “He sent them out to preach the kingdom of God and to heal” (Lk 9:2). Jesus took only these twelve apostles with him to the Last Supper, where he gave them the command, “Do this in remembrance of me” (Lk 22:19b).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Lk 6: 12-16" textlength="11" /><hc_bible ref="Lk 9: 2" textlength="7" /><hc_bible ref="Lk 22: 19" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Mt 16: 18" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 20: 21" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="551-553" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="567" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-did-jesus-call-apostles" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why did Jesus call apostles?

message.text: Jesus had a large circle of disciples around him, both men and women. From this circle he selected twelve men whom he called → APOSTLES (Lk 6:12-16). The apostles were specially trained by him and entrusted with various commissions: “He sent them out to preach the kingdom of God and to heal” (Lk 9:2). Jesus took only these twelve apostles with him to the Last Supper, where he gave them the command, “Do this in remembrance of me” (Lk 22:19b).

message.name: Why did Jesus choose the date of the Jewish feast of Passover for his death and Resurrection?

test.input: Why did Jesus choose the date of the Jewish feast of Passover for his death and Resurrection?
test.output: Jesus chose the Passover feast of his people Israel as a symbol for what was to happen through his death and Resurrection. As the people Israel were freed from slavery to Egypt, so Christ frees us from the slavery of sin and the power of death.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="1 Cor 5: 7" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="571-573" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-did-jesus-choose-the-date-of-the-jewish-feast-of-passover-for-his-death-and-resurrection" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why did Jesus choose the date of the Jewish feast of Passover for his death and Resurrection?

message.text: Jesus chose the Passover feast of his people Israel as a symbol for what was to happen through his death and Resurrection. As the people Israel were freed from slavery to Egypt, so Christ frees us from the slavery of sin and the power of death.

message.name: Why did Jesus have to redeem us on the Cross, of all places?

test.input: Why did Jesus have to redeem us on the Cross, of all places?
test.output: The Cross on which Jesus, although innocent, was cruelly executed is the place of utmost degradation and abandonment. Christ, our Redeemer, chose the Cross so as to bear the guilt of the world and to suffer the pain of the world. So he brought the world back home to God by his perfect love.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="613-617" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="622-623" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-did-jesus-have-to-redeem-us-on-the-cross-of-all-places" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why did Jesus have to redeem us on the Cross, of all places?

message.text: The Cross on which Jesus, although innocent, was cruelly executed is the place of utmost degradation and abandonment. Christ, our Redeemer, chose the Cross so as to bear the guilt of the world and to suffer the pain of the world. So he brought the world back home to God by his perfect love.

message.name: Why did Jesus wait thirty years to begin his public life?

test.output: Jesus wanted to share a normal life with us and thus sanctify our everyday routine.

trigger.value: Why did Jesus wait thirty years to begin his public life?

message.text: Jesus wanted to share a normal life with us and thus sanctify our everyday routine.

message.name: Why is Jesus Christ the Lord of the whole world?

message.name: Why is Mary a Virgin?

test.input: Why is Mary a Virgin?
test.output: God willed that Jesus Christ should have a true human mother but only God himself as his Father, because he wanted to make a new beginning that could be credited to him alone and not to earthly forces.

message.text: God willed that Jesus Christ should have a true human mother but only God himself as his Father, because he wanted to make a new beginning that could be credited to him alone and not to earthly forces.

test.output: Mary is our mother because Christ the Lord gave her to us as a mother.
