trigger.value: Why is Mary our mother also?

message.text: Mary is our mother because Christ the Lord gave her to us as a mother.

message.name: Why was Christ transfigured on the mountain?

test.input: Why was Christ transfigured on the mountain?
test.output: The Father wanted to reveal the divine glory of his Son even during Jesus’ earthly life. Christ’s Transfiguration was meant to help the disciples later to understand his death and Resurrection.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="554-556" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="568" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-was-christ-transfigured-on-the-mountain" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why was Christ transfigured on the mountain?

message.text: The Father wanted to reveal the divine glory of his Son even during Jesus’ earthly life. Christ’s Transfiguration was meant to help the disciples later to understand his death and Resurrection.

message.name: Why was Jesus led into temptation?

test.input: Why was Jesus led into temptation?
test.output: Jesus was truly human, and as part of that he was truly susceptible to temptation. In Jesus Christ we do not have the sort of redeemer “who is unable to sympathize with our weaknesses, but one who in every respect has been tempted as we are, yet without sinning” (Heb 4:15).
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="538-540" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="566" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-was-jesus-led-into-temptation" textlength="6" />

test.input: Could Jesus really be tempted at all?
test.output: Jesus was truly human, and as part of that he was truly susceptible to temptation. In Jesus Christ we do not have the sort of redeemer “who is unable to sympathize with our weaknesses, but one who in every respect has been tempted as we are, yet without sinning” (Heb 4:15).
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="538-540" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="566" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-was-jesus-led-into-temptation" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why was Jesus led into temptation?
Could Jesus really be tempted at all?

message.text: Jesus was truly human, and as part of that he was truly susceptible to temptation. In Jesus Christ we do not have the sort of redeemer “who is unable to sympathize with our weaknesses, but one who in every respect has been tempted as we are, yet without sinning” (Heb 4:15).

message.name: Why was a man of peace like Jesus condemned to death on a Cross?

test.input: Why was a man of peace like Jesus condemned to death on a Cross?
test.output: Jesus posed a decisive question to his contemporaries: Either he was acting with divine authority, or else he was an impostor, a blasphemer, and a violator of the Law and who had to be called to account.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="574-576" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-was-a-man-of-peace-like-jesus-condemned-to-death-on-a-cross" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why was a man of peace like Jesus condemned to death on a Cross?

message.text: Jesus posed a decisive question to his contemporaries: Either he was acting with divine authority, or else he was an impostor, a blasphemer, and a violator of the Law and who had to be called to account.

folder.name: I Believe in One, Holy, Catholic, and Apostolic Church

message.name: Are non-Catholic Christians our sisters and brothers also?

test.input: Are non-Catholic Christians our sisters and brothers also?
test.output: All baptized persons belong to the Church of Jesus Christ. That is why also those Christians who find themselves separated from the full communion of the Catholic Church are rightly called Christians and are therefore our sisters and brothers.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="817-819" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="are-non-catholic-christians-our-sisters-and-brothers-also" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Are non-Catholic Christians our sisters and brothers also?

message.text: All baptized persons belong to the Church of Jesus Christ. That is why also those Christians who find themselves separated from the full communion of the Catholic Church are rightly called Christians and are therefore our sisters and brothers.

message.name: Can bishops act and teach against the Pope, or the Pope against the bishops?

test.input: Can bishops act and teach against the Pope ?
test.output: Bishops cannot act and teach against the Pope, but only with him. In contrast, the Pope can make decisions in clearly defined cases even without the approval of the bishops.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="880-890" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="can-bishops-act-and-teach-against-the-pope-or-the-pope-against-the-bishops" textlength="6" />

test.input: Can the Pope act and teach against the bishops ?
test.output: Bishops cannot act and teach against the Pope, but only with him. In contrast, the Pope can make decisions in clearly defined cases even without the approval of the bishops.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="880-890" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="can-bishops-act-and-teach-against-the-pope-or-the-pope-against-the-bishops" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Can bishops act and teach against the Pope ?
Can the Pope act and teach against the bishops ?

message.text: Bishops cannot act and teach against the Pope, but only with him. In contrast, the Pope can make decisions in clearly defined cases even without the approval of the bishops.

message.name: How does the Church view other religions?

test.input: How does the Church view other religions?
test.output: The Church respects everything in other religions that is good and true. She respects and promotes freedom of religion as a human right. Yet she knows that Jesus Christ is the sole redeemer of all mankind. He alone is “the way, and the truth, and the life” (Jn 14:6).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 14: 6" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="841-845" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="846-848" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="how-does-the-church-view-other-religions" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: How does the Church view other religions?

message.text: The Church respects everything in other religions that is good and true. She respects and promotes freedom of religion as a human right. Yet she knows that Jesus Christ is the sole redeemer of all mankind. He alone is “the way, and the truth, and the life” (Jn 14:6).

message.name: How is the one, holy, catholic, and apostolic Church structured?

test.input: How is the one, holy, catholic, and apostolic Church structured?
test.output: I don't know how 1 is the holy.

trigger.value: How is the one, holy, catholic, and apostolic Church structured?

message.text: In the Church there are the laity and clerics. As children of God, they are of equal dignity. They have equally important but different tasks. The mission of the laity is to direct the whole world toward the kingdom of God. In addition, there are the ordained ministers (clerics), who have the duties of ecclesiastical governance, teaching, and sanctification. In both states of life, there are Christians who place themselves at God’s disposal in a special way through celibacy, poverty, and obedience (for example, consecrated religious).

message.name: What is the Pope’s responsibility?

test.input: What is the Pope’s responsibility?
test.output: As successor of St. Peter and head of the college of bishops, the Pope is the source and guarantor of the Church’s unity. He has the supreme pastoral authority and the final authority in doctrinal and disciplinary decisions.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="880-882" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="936-937" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-the-pope-s-responsibility" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is the Pope’s responsibility?

message.text: As successor of St. Peter and head of the college of bishops, the Pope is the source and guarantor of the Church’s unity. He has the supreme pastoral authority and the final authority in doctrinal and disciplinary decisions.

message.name: What is the lay vocation?

test.input: What is the lay vocation?
test.output: The laity are sent to engage in society so that the kingdom of God can grow among men.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="897-913" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="940-943" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-the-lay-vocation" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is the lay vocation?

message.text: The laity are sent to engage in society so that the kingdom of God can grow among men.

message.name: What is the relation between the Church and the Jews?

test.input: What is the relation between the Church and the Jews?
test.output: Jews are the “older brethren” of Christians, because God loved them first and spoke to them first. Jesus Christ as man is a Jew, and this fact unites us. The Church recognizes in him the Son of the living God, and this fact separates us. In awaiting the final coming of the Messiah we are one.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Mt 5: 17" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="839-840" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-the-relation-between-the-church-and-the-jews" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is the relation between the Church and the Jews?

message.text: Jews are the “older brethren” of Christians, because God loved them first and spoke to them first. Jesus Christ as man is a Jew, and this fact unites us. The Church recognizes in him the Son of the living God, and this fact separates us. In awaiting the final coming of the Messiah we are one.

message.name: What must we do for the unity of Christians?

test.input: What must we do for the unity of Christians?
test.output: In word and deed we must obey Christ, who expressly wills “that they may all be one” (Jn 17:21).
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 17: 1-23" textlength="11" /><hc_ccc ref="820-822" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-must-we-do-for-the-unity-of-christians" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What must we do for the unity of Christians?

message.text: In word and deed we must obey Christ, who expressly wills “that they may all be one” (Jn 17:21).

message.name: Who belongs to the Catholic Church?

test.input: Who belongs to the Catholic Church?
test.output: Anyone who, in union with the pope and the bishops, is united to Jesus Christ through profession of the Catholic faith and reception of the sacraments is in full communion with the Catholic Church.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="836-838" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="who-belongs-to-the-catholic-church" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Who belongs to the Catholic Church?

message.text: Anyone who, in union with the pope and the bishops, is united to Jesus Christ through profession of the Catholic faith and reception of the sacraments is in full communion with the Catholic Church.

message.name: Why can there be only one Church?

test.input: Why can there be only one Church?
test.output: Just as there is only one Christ, there can be only one Body of Christ, only one Bride of Christ, and therefore only one Church of Jesus Christ. He is the Head, the Church is the Body. Together they form the “whole Christ” (St. Augustine). Just as the body has many members yet is one, so too the one Church consists of and is made up of many particular churches (dioceses). Together they form the whole Christ.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Eph 4: 4-6" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="811-816" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="866" textlength="3" /><hc_ccc ref="870" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-can-there-be-only-one-church" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why can there be only one Church?

message.text: Just as there is only one Christ, there can be only one Body of Christ, only one Bride of Christ, and therefore only one Church of Jesus Christ. He is the Head, the Church is the Body. Together they form the “whole Christ” (St. Augustine). Just as the body has many members yet is one, so too the one Church consists of and is made up of many particular churches (dioceses). Together they form the whole Christ.

message.name: Why is the Church called apostolic?

test.input: Why is the Church called apostolic?
test.output: The Church is called apostolic because she was founded by the apostles, holds fast to their Tradition, and is governed by their successors.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Mt 10: 2-4" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="857-860" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="869-877" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-is-the-church-called-apostolic" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why is the Church called apostolic?

message.text: The Church is called apostolic because she was founded by the apostles, holds fast to their Tradition, and is governed by their successors.

message.name: Why is the Church called catholic?

test.input: Why is the Church called catholic?
test.output: “Catholic” (Greek kat’ holon) means related to the whole. The Church is catholic because Christ called her to profess the whole faith, to preserve all the sacraments, to administer them and proclaim the Good News to all; and he sent her to all nations.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Eph 1: 22-23" textlength="12" /><hc_ccc ref="830-831" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="849-856" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-is-the-church-called-catholic" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why is the Church called catholic?

message.text: “Catholic” (Greek kat’ holon) means related to the whole. The Church is catholic because Christ called her to profess the whole faith, to preserve all the sacraments, to administer them and proclaim the Good News to all; and he sent her to all nations.

message.name: Why is the Church holy?

test.input: Why is the Church holy?
test.output: The Church is holy, not because all her members are supposedly holy, but rather because God is holy and is at work in her. All the members of the Church are sanctified by Baptism.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Is 30: 15" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 6: 69" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="823-829" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-is-the-church-holy" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why is the Church holy?

message.text: The Church is holy, not because all her members are supposedly holy, but rather because God is holy and is at work in her. All the members of the Church are sanctified by Baptism.

message.name: Why is the Church not a democratic organization?

test.input: Why is the Church not a democratic organization?
test.output: Democracy operates on the principle that all power comes from the people. In the Church, however, all power comes from Christ. That is why the Church has a hierarchical structure. At the same time, however, Christ gave her a collegial structure as well.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="874-879" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-is-the-church-not-a-democratic-organization" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why is the Church not a democratic organization?

message.text: Democracy operates on the principle that all power comes from the people. In the Church, however, all power comes from Christ. That is why the Church has a hierarchical structure. At the same time, however, Christ gave her a collegial structure as well.

folder.name: I Believe in the Holy Spirit

message.name: How could the Holy Spirit work in, with, and through Mary?

test.input: How could the Holy Spirit work in, with, and through Mary?
test.output: Mary was totally responsive and open to God (Lk 1:38). Thus she was able to become the “Mother of God” through the working of the Holy Spirit—and as Christ’s Mother to become also the Mother of Christians, indeed, the Mother of all mankind.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Lk 1: 38" textlength="8" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 19: 25-27" textlength="12" /><hc_bible ref="Lk 1: 35" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="721-726" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="how-could-the-holy-spirit-work-in-with-and-through-mary" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: How could the Holy Spirit work in, with, and through Mary?

message.text: Mary was totally responsive and open to God (Lk 1:38). Thus she was able to become the “Mother of God” through the working of the Holy Spirit—and as Christ’s Mother to become also the Mother of Christians, indeed, the Mother of all mankind.

message.name: Under what names and signs does the Holy Spirit appear?

test.input: Under what names and signs does the Holy Spirit appear?
test.output: The Holy Spirit descends upon Jesus in the form of a dove. The first Christians experience the Holy Spirit as a healing ointment, living water, a raging storm, or a flaming fire. Jesus Christ himself speaks about the Counselor, Comforter, Teacher, and Spirit of Truth. In the sacraments of the Church, the Holy Spirit is bestowed through the imposition of hands and anointing with oil.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Gen 8: 10-11" textlength="12" /><hc_ccc ref="683-688" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="702-720" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="under-what-names-and-signs-does-the-holy-spirit-appear" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Under what names and signs does the Holy Spirit appear?

message.text: The Holy Spirit descends upon Jesus in the form of a dove. The first Christians experience the Holy Spirit as a healing ointment, living water, a raging storm, or a flaming fire. Jesus Christ himself speaks about the Counselor, Comforter, Teacher, and Spirit of Truth. In the sacraments of the Church, the Holy Spirit is bestowed through the imposition of hands and anointing with oil.

message.name: What does it mean to say that the Holy Spirit has “spoken through the prophets”?

test.input: What does it mean to say that the Holy Spirit has “spoken through the prophets”?
test.output: Already in the Old Covenant God filled men and women with the Spirit, so that they lifted up their voices for God, spoke in his name, and prepared the people for the coming of the Messiah.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Heb 1: 1-2" textlength="10" /><hc_ccc ref="683-688" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="702-720" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-that-the-holy-spirit-has-spoken-through-the-prophets" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say that the Holy Spirit has “spoken through the prophets”?

message.text: Already in the Old Covenant God filled men and women with the Spirit, so that they lifted up their voices for God, spoke in his name, and prepared the people for the coming of the Messiah.

message.name: What does it mean to say: I believe in the Holy Spirit?

test.input: What does it mean to say: I believe in the Holy Spirit?
test.output: To believe in the Holy Spirit means to worship him as God just like the Father and the Son. It means to believe that the Holy Spirit comes into our hearts so that we as children of God might know our Father in heaven. Moved by God’s Spirit, we can change the face of the earth.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 14: 16" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="683-686" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-i-believe-in-the-holy-spirit" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say: I believe in the Holy Spirit?

message.text: To believe in the Holy Spirit means to worship him as God just like the Father and the Son. It means to believe that the Holy Spirit comes into our hearts so that we as children of God might know our Father in heaven. Moved by God’s Spirit, we can change the face of the earth.

message.name: What does the Holy Spirit do in my life?

test.input: What does the Holy Spirit do in my life?
test.output: The Holy Spirit makes me receptive to God; he teaches me to pray and helps me to be there for others.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="738-741" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-the-holy-spirit-do-in-my-life" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does the Holy Spirit do in my life?

message.text: The Holy Spirit makes me receptive to God; he teaches me to pray and helps me to be there for others.

message.name: What does the Holy Spirit do in the Church?

test.input: What does the Holy Spirit do in the Church?
test.output: The Holy Spirit builds up the Church and impels her. He reminds her of her mission. He calls people into her service and sends them the necessary gifts. He leads us ever deeper into communion with the Triune God.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 16: 12-13" textlength="12" /><hc_bible ref="Gal 5: 22" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="733-741" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="747" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-the-holy-spirit-do-in-the-church" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does the Holy Spirit do in the Church?

message.text: The Holy Spirit builds up the Church and impels her. He reminds her of her mission. He calls people into her service and sends them the necessary gifts. He leads us ever deeper into communion with the Triune God.

message.name: What happened on Pentecost?

test.input: What happened on Pentecost?
test.output: Fifty days after his Resurrection, the Lord sent the Holy Spirit down from heaven upon his disciples. The age of the Church began.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Acts 2: 4-6" textlength="11" /><hc_ccc ref="731-733" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-happened-on-pentecost" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What happened on Pentecost?

message.text: Fifty days after his Resurrection, the Lord sent the Holy Spirit down from heaven upon his disciples. The age of the Church began.

message.name: What role does the Holy Spirit play in the life of Jesus?

test.input: What role does the Holy Spirit play in the life of Jesus?
test.output: Without the Holy Spirit, we cannot understand Jesus. In his life the presence of God’s Spirit, whom we call the Holy Spirit, was manifest in a unique way.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Mt 1: 18" textlength="8" /><hc_bible ref="Lk 4: 16-19" textlength="11" /><hc_bible ref="Mk 1: 12" textlength="8" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 19: 30" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 20: 20-21" textlength="12" /><hc_ccc ref="689-691" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="702-731" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-role-does-the-holy-spirit-play-in-the-life-of-jesus" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What role does the Holy Spirit play in the life of Jesus?

message.text: Without the Holy Spirit, we cannot understand Jesus. In his life the presence of God’s Spirit, whom we call the Holy Spirit, was manifest in a unique way.

folder.name: I Believe in... the Holy Catholic Church

message.name: What does it mean to say that the Church is the “Body of Christ”?

test.input: What does it mean to say that the Church is the “Body of Christ”?
test.output: Above all through the sacrements of Baptism and Holy eucharist, an inseparable union comes about between Jesus Christ and Christians. The union is so strong that it joins him and us like the head and members of a human body and makes us one.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="787-795" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-that-the-church-is-the-body-of-christ" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say that the Church is the “Body of Christ”?

message.text: Above all through the sacrements of Baptism and Holy eucharist, an inseparable union comes about between Jesus Christ and Christians. The union is so strong that it joins him and us like the head and members of a human body and makes us one.

message.name: What does it mean to say that the Church is the “Bride of Christ”?

test.input: What does it mean to say that the Church is the “Bride of Christ”?
test.output: Jesus Christ loves the Church as a bridegroom loves his bride. He binds himself to her forever and gives his life for her.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="796" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-that-the-church-is-the-bride-of-christ" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say that the Church is the “Bride of Christ”?

message.text: Jesus Christ loves the Church as a bridegroom loves his bride. He binds himself to her forever and gives his life for her.

message.name: What does it mean to say that the Church is the “Temple of the Holy Spirit”?

test.input: What does it mean to say that the Church is the “Temple of the Holy Spirit”?
test.output: The Church is the place in the world where the Holy Spirit is completely present.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="2 Cor 6: 16" textlength="11" /><hc_bible ref="Mt 18: 20" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="797-801" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="809" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-it-mean-to-say-that-the-church-is-the-temple-of-the-holy-spirit" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does it mean to say that the Church is the “Temple of the Holy Spirit”?

message.text: The Church is the place in the world where the Holy Spirit is completely present.

message.name: What does “Church” mean?

test.input: What does Church mean?
test.output: The Greek word for Church is “ekklesia” = those who are called forth. All of us who are baptized and believe in God are called forth by the Lord. Together we are the Church. Christ is, as Paul says, the Head of the Church. We are his body.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Col 1: 18" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="748-757" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-church-mean" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What does Church mean?
What is the Church?

message.text: The Greek word for Church is “ekklesia” = those who are called forth. All of us who are baptized and believe in God are called forth by the Lord. Together we are the Church. Christ is, as Paul says, the Head of the Church. We are his body.

message.name: What is the task of the Church?

test.input: What is the task of the Church?
test.output: The Church’s task is to make the kingdom of God, which has already begun with Jesus, germinate and grow in all nations.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 20: 21" textlength="9" /><hc_bible ref="Mt 28: 19-20" textlength="12" /><hc_ccc ref="763-769" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="774-776" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="780" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-the-task-of-the-church" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is the task of the Church?

message.text: The Church’s task is to make the kingdom of God, which has already begun with Jesus, germinate and grow in all nations.

message.name: What is unique about the People of God?

test.input: What is unique about the People of God?
test.output: The founder of this people is God the Father. Its leader is Jesus Christ. Its source of strength is the Holy Spirit. The entryway to the People of God is Baptism. Its dignity is the freedom of the children of God. Its law is love. If this people remains faithful to God and seeks first the kingdom of God, it changes the world.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Phil 2: 14-15" textlength="13" /><hc_ccc ref="781-786" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-unique-about-the-people-of-god" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is unique about the People of God?

message.text: The founder of this people is God the Father. Its leader is Jesus Christ. Its source of strength is the Holy Spirit. The entryway to the People of God is Baptism. Its dignity is the freedom of the children of God. Its law is love. If this people remains faithful to God and seeks first the kingdom of God, it changes the world.

message.name: Why does God want there to be a Church?

test.input: Why does God want there to be a Church?
test.output: God wills the Church because he wants to redeem us, not individually, but together. He wants to make all mankind his people.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Gen 4: 9" textlength="8" /><hc_ccc ref="758-781" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="802-804" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-does-god-want-there-to-be-a-church" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why does God want there to be a Church?

message.text: God wills the Church because he wants to redeem us, not individually, but together. He wants to make all mankind his people.

message.name: Why is the Church more than an institution?

test.input: Why is the Church more than an institution?
test.output: The Church is more than an institution because she is a mystery that is simultaneously human and divine.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="770-773" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="779" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-is-the-church-more-than-an-institution" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why is the Church more than an institution?

message.text: The Church is more than an institution because she is a mystery that is simultaneously human and divine.

message.name: What are creeds?

test.output: Creeds are brief formulas of faith that make it possible for all believers to make a common profession.

message.text: Creeds are brief formulas of faith that make it possible for all believers to make a common profession.

message.name: What does the Apostles’ Creed say?

test.input: What does the Apostles’ Creed say?
test.output: I believe in God, the Father almighty, Creator of heaven and earth, and in Jesus Christ, his only Son, our Lord, who was conceived by the Holy Spirit, born of the Virgin Mary, suffered under Pontius Pilate, was crucified, died and was buried; he descended into hell; on the third day he rose again from the dead; he ascended into heaven, and is seated at the right hand of God the Father almighty; from there he will come to judge the living and the dead. I believe in the Holy Spirit, the holy catholic Church, the communion of saints, the forgiveness of sins, the resurrection of the body, and life everlasting. Amen.
test.outputReferences: <hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-the-apostles-creed-say" textlength="6" />

I believe in the Holy Spirit, the holy catholic Church, the communion of saints, the forgiveness of sins, the resurrection of the body, and life everlasting. Amen.

message.text: I believe in God, the Father almighty, Creator of heaven and earth, and in Jesus Christ, his only Son, our Lord, who was conceived by the Holy Spirit, born of the Virgin Mary, suffered under Pontius Pilate, was crucified, died and was buried; he descended into hell; on the third day he rose again from the dead; he ascended into heaven, and is seated at the right hand of God the Father almighty; from there he will come to judge the living and the dead. message.name: What does the Nicene (Nicene-Constantinopolitan) Creed say?

test.input: What does the Nicene Creed say?
test.output:
I believe in one God, the Father almighty, maker of heaven and earth, of all things visible and invisible.
I believe in one Lord Jesus Christ, the Only Begotten Son of God, born of the Father before all ages. God from God, Light from Light, true God from true God, begotten, not made, consubstantial with the Father; through him all things were made. For us men and for our salvation he came down from heaven, and by the Holy Spirit was incarnate of the Virgin Mary, and became man. For our sake he was crucified under Pontius Pilate, he suffered death and was buried, and rose again on the third day in accordance with the Scriptures. He ascended into heaven and is seated at the right hand of the Father. He will come again in glory to judge the living and the dead and his kingdom will have no end.
I believe in the Holy Spirit, the Lord, the giver of life, who proceeds from the Father and the Son, who with the Father and the Son is adored and glorified, who has spoken through the prophets. I believe in one, holy, catholic and apostolic Church. I confess one baptism for the forgiveness of sins and I look forward to the resurrection of the dead and the life of the world to come. Amen.
test.outputReferences: <hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-does-the-nicene-nicene-constantinopolitan-creed-say" textlength="6" />

test.input: What does the Nicene-Constantinopolitan Creed say?

I believe in one Lord Jesus Christ, the Only Begotten Son of God, born of the Father before all ages. God from God, Light from Light, true God from true God, begotten, not made, consubstantial with the Father; through him all things were made. For us men and for our salvation he came down from heaven, and by the Holy Spirit was incarnate of the Virgin Mary, and became man. For our sake he was crucified under Pontius Pilate, he suffered death and was buried, and rose again on the third day in accordance with the Scriptures. He ascended into heaven and is seated at the right hand of the Father. He will come again in glory to judge the living and the dead and his kingdom will have no end.
I believe in the Holy Spirit, the Lord, the giver of life, who proceeds from the Father and the Son, who with the Father and the Son is adored and glorified, who has spoken through the prophets. I believe in one, holy, catholic and apostolic Church. I confess one baptism for the forgiveness of sins and I look forward to the resurrection of the dead and the life of the world to come. Amen.

message.name: Why does the faith require definitions and formulas?

test.input: Why does the faith require definitions and formulas?
test.output: Faith is not about empty words but about reality. In the Church, condensed formulas of faith developed over the course of time; with their help we can contemplate, express, learn, hand on, celebrate, and live out this reality.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="170-174" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-does-the-faith-require-definitions-and-formulas" textlength="6" />

folder.name: Why We Are Able to Believe

message.name: Can the Church err in questions of faith?

test.input: Can the Church err in questions of faith?
test.output: The faithful as a whole cannot err in faith, because Jesus promised his disciples that he would send them the Spirit of truth and keep them in the truth.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 14: 17" textlength="9" /><hc_ccc ref="80-82" textlength="5" /><hc_ccc ref="85-87" textlength="5" /><hc_ccc ref="92" textlength="2" /><hc_ccc ref="100" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="can-the-church-err-in-questions-of-faith" textlength="6" />

message.text: The faithful as a whole cannot err in faith, because Jesus promised his disciples that he would send them the Spirit of truth and keep them in the truth.

message.name: How can Sacred Scripture be “truth” if not everything in it is right?

test.input: How can Sacred Scripture be “truth” if not everything in it is right?
test.output: The Bible is not meant to convey precise historical information or scientific findings to us. Moreover, the authors were children of their time. Their forms of expression are influenced by the sometimes inadequate cultural images of the world around them. Nevertheless, everything that man must know about God and the way of his salvation is found with infallible certainty in Sacred Scripture.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="106-107" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="109" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="how-can-sacred-scripture-be-truth-if-not-everything-in-it-is-right" textlength="6" />

Their forms of expression are influenced by the sometimes inadequate cultural images of the world around them. Nevertheless, everything that man must know about God and the way of his salvation is found with infallible certainty in Sacred Scripture.

message.name: What is the right way to read the Bible?

test.input: What is the right way to read the Bible?
test.output: The right way to read Sacred Scripture is to read it prayerfully, in other words, with the help of the Holy Spirit, under whose influence it came into being. It is God’s Word and contains God’s essential communication to us.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="109-119" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="137" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-is-the-right-way-to-read-the-bible" textlength="6" />

message.name: What role does Sacred Scripture play in the Church?

test.input: What role does Sacred Scripture play in the Church?
test.output: The Church draws her life and strength from Sacred Scripture.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="103-104" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="131-133" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="141" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-role-does-sacred-scripture-play-in-the-church" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What role does Sacred Scripture play in the Church?

message.text: The Church draws her life and strength from Sacred Scripture.

message.name: What significance does the New Testament have for Christians?

test.input: What significance does the New Testament have for Christians?
test.output: In the New Testament God’s Revelation is completed. The four Gospels according to Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John are the centerpiece of Sacred Scripture and the most precious treasure of the Church. In them the Son of God shows himself as he is and encounters us. In the Acts of the Apostles we learn about the beginnings of the Church and the working of the Holy Spirit. In the letters written by the apostles, all facets of human life are set in the light of Christ. In the Book of Revelation we foresee the end of the ages.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="124-127" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="128-130" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="140" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="what-significance-does-the-new-testament-have-for-christians" textlength="6" />

The four Gospels according to Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John are the centerpiece of Sacred Scripture and the most precious treasure of the Church. In them the Son of God shows himself as he is and encounters us. In the Acts of the Apostles we learn about the beginnings of the Church and the working of the Holy Spirit. In the letters written by the apostles, all facets of human life are set in the light of Christ. In the Book of Revelation we foresee the end of the ages.

message.name: What significance does the Old Testament have for Christians?

test.input: What significance does the Old Testament have for Christians?
test.output: In the Old Testament God reveals himself as the Creator and preserver of the world and as the leader and instructor of mankind. The Old Testament books are also God’s Word and Sacred Scripture. Without the Old Testament, we cannot understand Jesus.

message.text: In the Old Testament God reveals himself as the Creator and preserver of the world and as the leader and instructor of mankind. The Old Testament books are also God’s Word and Sacred Scripture. Without the Old Testament, we cannot understand Jesus.

message.name: Why did God have to show himself in order for us to be able to know what he is like ?

test.input: Why did God have to show himself in order for us to be able to know what he is like ?
test.output: Man can know by reason that God exists, but not what God is really like. Yes because God would very much like to be known, he has revealed himself.

message.name: Can we know the existence of God by our reason?

test.input: Can we know the existence of God by our reason?
test.output: Yes. Human reason can know God with certainty.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="31-36" textlength="5" /><hc_ccc ref="44-47" textlength="5" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="can-we-know-the-existence-of-god-by-our-reason" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Can we know the existence of God by our reason?

message.text: Yes. Human reason can know God with certainty.

message.name: Why do people deny that God exists, if they can know him by reason?

test.input: Why do people deny that God exists, if they can know him by reason?
test.output: I don't know why people deny if God can know itself by the reason then it exists.

trigger.value: Why do people deny that God exists, if they can know him by reason?

message.text: To know the invisible God is a great challenge for the human mind. Many are scared off by it. Another reason why some do not want to know God is because they would then have to change their life. Anyone who says that the question about God is meaningless because it cannot be answered is making things too easy for himself.

message.name: Why do we seek God?

test.input: Why do we seek God?
test.output: God has placed in our hearts a longing to seek and find him. St. Augustine says, "You have made us for yourself, and our heart is restless until it rests in you." We call this longing for God religion.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Acts 17: 27-28" textlength="14" /><hc_ccc ref="27-30" textlength="5" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-do-we-seek-god" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why do we seek God?

message.text: God has placed in our hearts a longing to seek and find him. St. Augustine says, "You have made us for yourself, and our heart is restless until it rests in you." We call this longing for God religion.

message.name: Faith - what is it?

test.input: What is faith?
test.output:
Faith is knowledge and trust. It has seven characteristics: \hc_resource_html=#en_US#
  • Faith is a sheer gift of God, which we receive when we fervently ask for it.
  • Faith is the supernatural power that is absolutely necessary if we are to attain salvation.
  • Faith requires the free will and clear understanding of a person when he accepts the divine invitation.
  • Faith is absolutely certain, because Jesus guarantees it.
  • Faith is incomplete unless it leads to active love.
  • Faith grows when we listen more and more carefully to God’s Word and enter a lively exchange with him in prayer.
  • Faith gives us even now a foretaste of the joy of heaven.
\
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="153-165" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="179-180" textlength="7" /><hc_ccc ref="183-184" textlength="7" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="faith-what-is-it" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: What is faith?

message.text:
Faith is knowledge and trust. It has seven characteristics:
  • Faith is a sheer gift of God, which we receive when we fervently ask for it.
  • Faith is the supernatural power that is absolutely necessary if we are to attain salvation.
  • Faith requires the free will and clear understanding of a person when he accepts the divine invitation.
  • Faith is absolutely certain, because Jesus guarantees it.
  • Faith is incomplete unless it leads to active love.
  • Faith grows when we listen more and more carefully to God’s Word and enter a lively exchange with him in prayer.
  • Faith gives us even now a foretaste of the joy of heaven.

message.name: How can we respond to God when he speaks to us?

test.input: How can we respond to God when he speaks to us?
test.output: To respond to God means to believe him.

trigger.value: How can we respond to God when he speaks to us?

message.text: To respond to God means to believe him.

message.name: How does one go about believing?

trigger.value: How does one go about believing?

message.text: Someone who believes is seeking a personal union with God and is ready to believe God in everything that he shows (reveals) about himself.

message.name: Is there a contradiction between faith and science?

test.input: Is there a contradiction between faith and science?
test.output: There is no insoluble contradiction between faith and science, because there cannot be two kinds of truth.

trigger.value: Is there a contradiction between faith and science?

message.text: There is no insoluble contradiction between faith and science, because there cannot be two kinds of truth.

message.name: What does my faith have to do with the Church?

test.input: What does my faith have to do with the Church?
test.output: No one can believe alone and by himself, just as no one can live alone and by himself. We receive the faith from the Church and live it out in fellowship with the people with whom we share our faith.

message.text: No one can believe alone and by himself, just as no one can live alone and by himself. We receive the faith from the Church and live it out in fellowship with the people with whom we share our faith.

message.name: Why are we on earth?

test.output: We are on earth in order to know, in order to love God, in order to do good according to Will and in order to go to someday Heaven.

test.output: We are on earth in order to know and to love God, to do good according to his will, and to go someday to heaven.

message.name: Why did God create us?

test.output: God created us out of free and unselfish love.
test.outputReferences: <hc_ccc ref="1-3" textlength="3" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT" resourceid="why-did-god-create-us" textlength="6" />

trigger.value: Why did God create us?

message.text: God created us out of free and unselfish love.

message.name: Believing in God, how does that work?

test.input: Believing in God, how does that work?

trigger.value: Believing in God, how does that work?

message.text: Believing in God means: I put all my trust in him who loves me most. I accept what God reveals about himself. I try to do what he tells me.

message.name: Believing in God, how does that work? (continuation)
message.text: Believing in God means being safe and secure with him. God loves us. We do not need to be afraid. With him, we can bring out the best in ourselves!

message.name: Can I talk to God?

test.input: Can I talk to God?
test.output: Yes. Talk to him! Ask him to make himself known in your heart.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Ps 139: 16" textlength="10" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT for Kids" resourceid="can-i-talk-to-god" textlength="15" />

trigger.value: Can I talk to God?

message.text: Yes. Talk to him! Ask him to make himself known in your heart.

message.name: Can I talk to God? (continuation)
message.text: Not only can you talk to God, God is already waiting for you. It does not matter if you are riding your bike or waiting for a bus. Just talk to him.

message.name: Can we believe whatever we want?

test.input: Can we believe whatever we want?
test.output: Yes, but only the truth is worth believing. Christians do not invent the faith; they trust in Jesus Christ. He has brought us the truth about God. It is written in the Bible and in the living Tradition of the Church.
test.outputReferences: <hc_source name="YOUCAT for Kids" resourceid="can-we-believe-whatever-we-want" textlength="15" />

trigger.value: Can we believe whatever we want?

message.text: Yes, but only the truth is worth believing. Christians do not invent the faith; they trust in Jesus Christ. He has brought us the truth about God. It is written in the Bible and in the living Tradition of the Church.

message.name: Can we believe whatever we want? (continuation)
message.text: In the Church, together we live out what we have learned from Jesus. We should bring this faith to all people. Even though God is close to everyone, he asks us to share our faith with each other.

message.name: Can we know God?

test.input: Can we know God?
test.output: Yes, but not without his help. God is greater than all of our images and all of our thoughts. God is a great mystery.
test.outputReferences: <hc_source name="YOUCAT for Kids" resourceid="can-we-know-god" textlength="15" />

trigger.value: Can we know God?

message.text: Yes, but not without his help. God is greater than all of our images and all of our thoughts. God is a great mystery.

message.name: Can we know God? (continuation)
message.text: God wants us to know and love him. That is why he shows himself to us. That is called "revelation".

message.name: How do we know that God exists?

test.input: How do we know that God exists?
test.output: We know that God exists because we see his traces everywhere.
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Acts 17: 28" textlength="11" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT for Kids" resourceid="how-do-we-know-that-god-exists" textlength="15" />

trigger.value: How do we know that God exists?

message.text: We know that God exists because we see his traces everywhere.

message.name: How do we know that God exists? (continuation)
message.text: Look at everything: the sun in the sky, the stars at night, the forests, the mountains, the seas, and the rivers, the big animals and the small, the people on all the continents. God has made all that.

message.name: How is knowledge about God passed on?

test.input: How is knowledge about God passed on?
test.output: Among God's people, from the beginning, knowledge of God was passed on through stories about him, which were written down in the Bible. They are celebrated at Mass and proclaimed by the Church.
test.outputReferences: <hc_source name="YOUCAT for Kids" resourceid="how-is-knowledge-about-god-passed-on" textlength="15" />

trigger.value: How is knowledge about God passed on?

message.text: Among God's people, from the beginning, knowledge of God was passed on through stories about him, which were written down in the Bible. They are celebrated at Mass and proclaimed by the Church.

message.name: How is knowledge about God passed on? (continuation 2)
message.text: Sometimes we learn about God from the experiences of others. When Christians recount the ways God has showed himself to them, guided them in their lives, or healed them, they give witness to their faith.

message.name: How is knowledge about God passed on? (continuation)
message.text: The Church is the community where experiences with the living God are correctly understood and passed on from generation to generation. Every Christian who lives by his faith has a story to tell. Christian parents and grandparents try to pass on their faith to their children and grandchildren.

message.name: Where does the world and everything that is come from ?

trigger.value: Where does the world and everything that is come from ?

message.text: Everything that is comes from God.

message.name: Why do I exist?

test.input: Why do I exist?
test.output: You are here because God wants you.
test.outputReferences: <hc_source name="YOUCAT for Kids" resourceid="why-do-i-exist" textlength="15" />

trigger.value: Why do I exist?

message.text: You are here because God wants you.

message.name: Why do I exist? (continuation)

test.input: Who knows me ?
test.outputReferences: <hc_bible ref="Jn 3: 16" textlength="8" /><hc_bible ref="1 Jn 4: 8-10" textlength="12" /><hc_bible ref="1 Jn 4: 18-21" textlength="13" /><hc_bible ref="Rom 8: 37-39" textlength="12" /><hc_bible ref="Eph 2: 4-7" textlength="10" /><hc_bible ref="Jn 15: 9-10" textlength="11" /><hc_bible ref="Eph 3: 16-19" textlength="12" /><hc_bible ref="Prov 8: 17" textlength="10" /><hc_source name="YOUCAT for Kids" resourceid="why-do-i-exist-continuation" textlength="15" />

message.text: God knows you. God loves you beyond measure, and he wants to make you happy.
